newsitem.title: ESTONIA: Estonian Saku brewer 1996 profit falls.
newsitem.headline: Estonian Saku brewer 1996 profit falls.

text.p: Estonia's leading brewer Saku, jointly owned by Finnish Hartwall and Nordic brewer Pripps, said on Monday its 1996 profit fell as sales of beer and beer consumption decreased.
The company is majority owned by Baltic Beverage Ltd, formed by Hartwall and Pripps, itself jointly owned by Norway's Orkla and Volvo.
Saku said in a statement that its 1996 profit fell to 27.3 million kroons after 29.68 million kroons in 1995.
Saku, quoted on the over-the-counter market of the stock exchange, said it continued to hold 50 percent of the market.
However, it said imported beer sales rose from seven to 10 percent of the market which hit other local beer producers, who lost three percent to hold 40 percent of the market.
Saku's 1996 sales of beer decreased by 4.5 percent to 25.6 million litres versus 26.8 million litres in 1995, Saku added.
Imported beer sales increased in Estonia by one million litres to five million litres in 1996, the statement added.
It added that the size of the Estonian beer market decreased four percent in 1996 to 50.6 million litres and beer consumption fell to 34 litres of beer per person per year from 35 litres.
